criteria.name: Layer Independence
criteria.description: Each layer is independently useful without requiring other layers to make sense

ratings.1: Layers tightly coupled, can't understand one without seeing all others
ratings.3: Layers mostly independent but some concepts leak between layers
ratings.5: Each layer fully modular: strategic useful to executives, tactical to managers, operational to engineers independently

criteria.name: Appropriate Number of Layers
criteria.description: Uses 3-5 layers optimally; not too few (loses nuance) or too many (overhead)

ratings.1: Too few (<3) or too many (>5) layers; either oversimplified or excessively complex
ratings.3: Acceptable number of layers but some redundancy or gaps between levels
ratings.5: Optimal 3-5 layers, each clearly named with distinct role and appropriate abstraction gap

criteria.name: Upward Consistency
criteria.description: Operations implement tactics, tactics achieve strategy (bottom-up validation)

ratings.1: Operations don't implement tactics, or tactics don't achieve strategy; significant gaps or orphans
ratings.3: Most operations map to tactics and tactics to strategy, but some orphans or unclear mappings
ratings.5: Complete upward consistency: every operation implements a tactic, every tactic achieves strategic principle

criteria.name: Downward Consistency
criteria.description: Strategy can be executed with chosen tactics, tactics implementable operationally

ratings.1: Strategy infeasible with tactics, or tactics can't be implemented; missing critical tactics/operations
ratings.3: Strategy mostly achievable but some gaps in tactics or operations; feasibility concerns
ratings.5: Complete downward consistency: strategy achievable with tactics, tactics implementable with available resources/skills

criteria.name: Lateral Consistency
criteria.description: No contradictions among parallel choices at same layer (e.g., tactics don't conflict)

ratings.1: Multiple contradictions at same layer (e.g., conflicting tactics or incompatible operations)
ratings.3: Mostly consistent but some tension between parallel choices requiring tradeoffs
ratings.5: Full lateral consistency: all parallel choices compatible or explicitly prioritized with clear tradeoffs

criteria.name: Abstraction Gap Size
criteria.description: Each layer translates to 3-10 elements at layer below; not too large (confusing) or too small (redundant)

ratings.1: Abstraction gaps inappropriate: jumps too large (>20 elements) or too small (<2 elements)
ratings.3: Acceptable gaps but some layers have irregular expansion (e.g., 1→30 or 1→1)
ratings.5: Optimal gaps: each strategic element → 3-10 tactical, each tactical → 3-10 operational

criteria.name: Bidirectional Propagation
criteria.description: Changes propagate both top-down (strategy → ops) and bottom-up (constraints → strategy)

ratings.1: One-way only: strategy changes don't update ops, or operational constraints ignored at strategic layer
ratings.3: Bidirectional but incomplete: some changes propagated, others missed or delayed
ratings.5: Full bidirectional propagation: strategic changes cascade down, operational constraints escalate up with clarification

criteria.name: Emergence Recognition
criteria.description: Bottom-up patterns identified and strategic implications recognized

ratings.1: No emergence detection; unintended consequences surprise stakeholders; reactive only
ratings.3: Some emergence recognized post-hoc but not systematically monitored; pattern recognition ad-hoc
ratings.5: Proactive emergence detection: operational behavior monitored, patterns identified, strategic implications assessed

criteria.name: Clear Layer Contracts
criteria.description: Explicit dependencies and requirements documented between layers

ratings.1: Implicit contracts; unclear what each layer requires from others or guarantees upward
ratings.3: Contracts partially documented but some assumptions implicit or dependencies unclear
ratings.5: Explicit contracts: strategic invariants clear, tactical requirements documented, operational guarantees specified

criteria.name: Communication Translation
criteria.description: Content translated appropriately for different audiences at different abstraction levels

ratings.1: Same content for all audiences; executives get operational details or engineers get only strategy
ratings.3: Some translation but inconsistent; occasional abstraction mismatches for audience
ratings.5: Perfect translation: executives get strategic view, managers tactical, engineers operational; all maintain causal links

guidance_by_type.rationale: Architectural layers must be independently useful and implement each other consistently. Contracts prevent integration failures.
Strategy must be executable (downward) and responsive to operational reality (upward). Translation ensures stakeholder alignment.
Org changes create emergent behavior (Conway's Law). Lateral consistency prevents conflicting policies across departments.
Explanations at different depths require appropriate abstraction gaps and clear translation without losing coherence.
Product vision must translate to executable features (down) and user feedback must inform strategy (up via emergence).

guidance_by_complexity.notes: Focus on basic consistency checks. Three layers (strategy/tactics/ops) sufficient. Independence less critical for simple domains.
Cross-functional requires strong translation between audiences. Lateral consistency critical when multiple teams involved.
Large scale demands formal contracts, systematic emergence detection, and rigorous bidirectional propagation to maintain alignment.

common_failure_modes.name: Layer Skipping
common_failure_modes.symptom: Jump directly from strategy to operations without tactical layer (e.g., 'We need to scale' → 'Deploy Kubernetes')
common_failure_modes.detection: Gap in reasoning: no intermediate 'what' layer between 'why' (strategy) and 'how' (operations)

common_failure_modes.name: Tight Coupling
common_failure_modes.symptom: Can't understand strategic layer without seeing code, or operational layer without re-deriving strategy
common_failure_modes.detection: Stakeholders can't consume single layer independently; requires full context to make sense
common_failure_modes.fix: Make each layer standalone: strategic principles clear without ops, operations executable without strategy rederivation

common_failure_modes.name: Too Many Layers
common_failure_modes.symptom: 6+ layers with redundant distinctions (Vision, Mission, Strategy, Goals, Objectives, Tactics, Tasks, Subtasks...)
common_failure_modes.detection: People debate which layer something belongs to; layers blur together; can't clearly name each layer's role
common_failure_modes.fix: Consolidate to 3-5 layers by merging redundant levels (e.g., Goals + Objectives → single Tactical layer)

common_failure_modes.name: Orphan Operations
common_failure_modes.symptom: Operations that don't implement any tactic (e.g., 'Cache user data unencrypted' when tactics are all about security)
common_failure_modes.detection: Trace operation upward: which tactic does it implement? If answer is 'none', it's an orphan
common_failure_modes.fix: Either add tactic it implements (revealing implicit strategy) or remove operation (violates strategy)

common_failure_modes.name: Infeasible Strategy
common_failure_modes.symptom: Strategic principle can't be achieved with available tactics/operations (e.g., 'Sub-second latency globally' but no CDN tactics)
common_failure_modes.detection: Downward trace from strategy: can we execute this with chosen tactics? Do we have operations to implement?
common_failure_modes.fix: Either add missing tactics/operations or refine strategy to acknowledge constraints ('Sub-second in primary regions')

common_failure_modes.name: Lateral Contradictions
common_failure_modes.symptom: Parallel tactics conflict (e.g., 'Microservices for independence' + 'Shared database for simplicity' → incompatible)
common_failure_modes.detection: Pairwise comparison of all choices at same layer: do any contradict or compete for resources?
common_failure_modes.fix: Resolve by prioritizing based on strategic importance or refining to make compatible (regional databases)

common_failure_modes.name: One-Way Propagation
common_failure_modes.symptom: Strategy changes but operations don't update, or operational constraints discovered but strategy unchanged
common_failure_modes.detection: Strategic shift announced but teams still executing old tactics; or performance issues known but strategy still claims 'sub-second'
common_failure_modes.fix: Implement bidirectional propagation: cascade strategic changes down, escalate operational constraints up for clarification

common_failure_modes.name: Missed Emergence
common_failure_modes.symptom: Unintended consequences surprise stakeholders (e.g., microservices slowed delivery due to coordination overhead - Conway's Law)
common_failure_modes.detection: Operational behavior doesn't match tactical expectations; patterns emerge that weren't designed
common_failure_modes.fix: Monitor operational metrics, identify emerging tactical patterns, recognize strategic implications, adjust strategy if needed

common_failure_modes.name: Wrong Abstraction for Audience
common_failure_modes.symptom: Presenting operational details to executives (AWS regions) or only strategic vision to engineers ('we need to scale')
common_failure_modes.detection: Audience confused, asks for different level of detail, or can't take action based on info provided
common_failure_modes.fix: Translate to appropriate layer: executives get strategic (why/outcomes), engineers get operational (how/tech stack)

common_failure_modes.name: Implicit Layer Contracts
common_failure_modes.symptom: Unclear what each layer requires from others; integration failures when layers don't meet unstated assumptions
common_failure_modes.detection: Frequent misalignment discovered late; 'I thought tactical layer X meant Y' disagreements
common_failure_modes.fix: Document explicit contracts: strategic invariants, tactical requirements, operational guarantees at each layer boundary

overall_guidance.excellent: Score ≥4.5: Exemplary layered reasoning. Clear, independent layers (3-5) with full consistency (upward/downward/lateral). Bidirectional propagation maintains alignment. Emergence proactively detected. Communication perfectly translated for all audiences.
overall_guidance.good: Score 3.5-4.4: Solid layered reasoning. Mostly consistent layers with some minor gaps. Bidirectional propagation exists but could be more systematic. Good translation for primary audiences.
overall_guidance.needs_improvement: Score <3.5: Significant gaps. Layer skipping, tight coupling, contradictions, one-way propagation, or missed emergence. Communication confuses audiences with wrong abstraction level.
overall_guidance.key_principle: Layered reasoning maintains consistency: lower layers implement upper layers, upper layers constrain lower layers. Good layers are independently useful, appropriately numerous (3-5), and bidirectionally propagate changes.
